job_title: Registered Nurse in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Salary, although not even worth it when you consider the risk involved
cons: Terrible nurse to patient ratios, wildly unsafe, with the added bonus of highly punitive administration. Essentially being put in a position to fail, then being blamed if god forbid you do fail. Proclaims to have total transparency when nursing administration is barely visible and HR is a nightmare to try and get ahold of when you need them. More responsibilities being constantly delegated to already overburdened RNs. No charge nurses off care to help put out fires, every charge nurse is already overburdened with their own team and unable to help others when they need it. The turn-over is outrageous. Do not work here. My former unit was shut down over and over and my co-workers and I were forced to become the float team without our consent, constantly receiving the most dangerous and unsafe assignments, and not receiving the same compensation as the float RNs in our hospital. This is the kind of stuff that happens regularly at this organization. Our hospital was unionized and still had no ability to protect us from a completely unmanageable workload and constant increase in responsibilities.

review_title: A Better Choice in the Mess that is Healthcare
job_title: Registered Nurse in New York, NY
pros: Nursing staffing is horrible everywhere, but not so bad in the Columbia campus at least. Patient ratios are pretty good in most ICUs here. The culture of the my unit is pleasant to work in, and I enjoy working with my colleagues. The unit is very high acuity so you are certainly learning a lot every day. The reputation of the hospital precedes itself and my colleagues definitely are some of the smartest minds I work with.
cons: Staffing is an issue in all hospitals, and while it isn’t the worst that I’ve seen here, it’s still present. Wish there was more PCTs to help with patient care. It’s also amusing to see one of the top hospitals in the country is also giving us snacks and wellness coaches instead of giving $$$ to burned out healthcare workers.

job_title: Registered Nurse in New York, NY
pros: Unionized hospital with NYSNA RN’a and 1199 tech members, so it has the potential to have the same problems as city government hospitals. However, the institution has more to “budget” for better salaries, equipment, personnel, and incentives to perform. Organization and leadership show they try to help (better than city govt hospitals, which give 0 help). Can climb clinical ladder. The whiter your colleagues become, the better conditions you get. I hear the non-unionized NYC hospitals like Sloan Kettering and NYP Weill-Cornell are a step above in workplace quality but caters to NYC’s microaggressively racist out-of-touch-with-reality elite, and I don’t see a good reason to leave a unionized workplace. Unit based governance with supporting management allows for staff to have a voice on the unit’s workflow and direct resources to supporting staff.
cons: Haven’t seen much of a salary increase according to union contracts. If Elon Musk didn’t donate masks, I’m afraid leadership wouldn’t have had enough PPE prepped for us. They even discouraged us from wearing masks in March 2020 so to not alarm patients.

job_title: Physician Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Good reputation and resume builder. Attracts a lot of bright, young, motivated people.
cons: They will underpay you. It is a teaching hospital and there are a lot of frustrations that come with that. As a PA, your education is not a priority and we sort of take what ever roles the residents don’t want. Fine for a first job, not a sustainable place to work and the turn over of PAs is extremely high. This has been the case for years but administration does not see a problem with this so nothing will likely change. This institution repeatedly produces the next generation of world class NYU & Columbia PAs, horrible retention at this hospital.

job_title: Psychiatric Technician in New York, NY
pros: Working for New-York Presbyterian helped me to gain insight on my long-term career goals and also led me to begin my educational career. I was employed for a total of three years with this organization and within that period of time I held three different positions. There is so much room for growth, the salary is always competitive and they grant special incentives for working holidays. My first position held was as a dining host for the main hospital, one year later I was able to advance and serve the patients on the amenities unit. My last position held was as a Psychiatric technician. Although I had to end my employment with the company I know what I want to do with my future and I have New-York Presbyterian and all of the wonderful staff, management and an array of patients to thank.
cons: Although there are so many extra hours available for part-timers having more availability of full-time positions would've been ideal. Part-timers are eligible for benefits just on a smaller scale in comparison to full-time employees even if they work just as many hours.

review_title: Excellent if you're paid what you're worth
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Cortlandt Manor, NY
pros:
One man's PRO is another man's CON - so, I won't differentiate between them - you take your pick:

It is a true mom-and-pop shop. Everyone knows everyone else and everything about them. Naturally, it helps to know the right people. Many business decisions are made on emotional criteria. Penny wise in grassroots employee reimbursement is often pound foolish in underutilized mega-projects.

Employee satisfaction is high, though. Management keep grassroots employees 'in the know' about the state of affairs at the hospital, and this minimizes speculation. Employees are appreciated, but you have to be highly visible employee for that. Management often promises to be accessible to employees, but as with any other place there are inevitably more important issues that need attention.

Do not settle for a pay that is lower than you are worth - it will not increase as you gain advanced degrees, certifications, and become more experienced - you will stay at the pay you started. There will be an annual raise based on a performance evaluation, but it will take years before that amount becomes significant enough to differentiate from your starting salary.

Professional advancement also depends on who you network with.  Opportunities are few and far between.  The loudest complainers are pacified first. So, if you're quiet and dutiful, do not expect to be noticed and offered opportunities.
cons: Pick your PROs and CONs from the description above

review_title: Compromising standard of care due to inadequate resources and inappropriate delays for inpatients
job_title: Housestafff At Columbia Campus in New York, NY
pros: The physicians are excellent and extremely dedicated to their patients. The senior management seems dedicated to making changes, but so far it’s not enough.
cons: As a new member of the housestaff I have been told from day 1 that we are routinely forced to compromise on the quality of care provided due to unavailability of resources. For example, I had two inpatients on my service wait over 48 hours for a routine MRI. Another patient who was scheduled for  two diagnostic and therapeutic procedures in the same day was delayed >2 hours due to transport and as a result was unable to have the second procedure. In the morning when discussing our plan, we knew this would happen and were  forced  to decide which of the two was more important, gambling that the second would not happen. Since it was a Friday, this meant the patient was hospitalized throughout the entire weekend. The 2 hour delay in transport meant the patient spent 2 extra nights in the hospital unnecessarily. These are just two examples of how frustrating it is to work in an environment where you can’t even rely on basic functions of the hospital, like transport and diagnostic imaging.

job_title: Senior Staff Nurse in New York, NY
pros: Nurses are able to make changes to policy as long as they are evidence based. I was supported by MDs and nursing management for the projects I developed. Many managers are flexible and supportive but the culture varies greatly from unit to unit. The management positions have high turnover. Good pay, healthcare benefits are good, although they were better before the hospital switched to Aetna. Good paid time off and opportunities for career advancement. Generally cooperative and positive interactions between services. Good collaboration between doctors and nurses.
cons: Unit based decisions are influenced by nursing, but hospital wide policy is not. Major changes are made to the hospital policies that directly affect nursing without nursing input. For example, nurses were not allowed to have water outside of the break room (and who has time to go to break???) until a nurse had a seizure from dehydration. Now we can have water in closed containers.  Units are re-designed without input from nursing, even though we are the ones using the units. There is no maximum number of patients you can have, no matter the acuity. Nurses are seen as numbers to meet staffing targets despite specialty, length of service or skill level. Management has repeatedly failed to address this issue.

job_title: RN Care Manager in New York, NY
pros:
- Excellent benefits & competitive salary

cons:
- Bigger the campus (i.e. Columbia/Cornell) bigger the pond, i.e. you can feel like you're lost in the crowd, impersonal.
- Culture is slow to change, as the enterprise is so big and across the entire the city
- Management can be tough sometimes but I guess its their jobs to be tough on the people.

review_title: Fantastic place to work and grow-- up to a point.
job_title: Black Belt in New York, NY
pros: Its a place that is really helping people and saving lives.  From a quality of life perspective: as an employee, there is a great respect for work-life balance--: the most incredible vacation allotment, the best healthcare benefits of anyone I know, a retirement contribution plan in a different league from any other company I've heard of, and a general respect for work-life balance adhered to even by management. Its a large place, but that means there is a lot of room to move around over the years-- I've never run into a place where I've met as many people that have worked at the same place for over 20 years as NYP.
cons: Fairly political, and career advancement is definitely depending on political connections within the organization.  Senior management seems to have good intentions and hearts in the right place, but not always executed in the most common-sense way.  Found it hard to advance past a certain level because of lack of personal connections throughout the organization.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Do the minimum amount of work so you will not be noticed. A very large organization so they won't pay attention to you. They will raise your salary so that it is competative with other hospitals that have your same job title. Health benefits are good and non-expensive.
cons:
Unless you are an obey every order without questioning it, then you will not advance here.
They want people that shake their heads yes at everything their supersivor wants. Do not ask questions or make suggestions to improve the work place if you want to get promoted here. Be as loyal as an animal and you will be rewarded with a promotion.

This is not a place for out-side-of-the-box thinkers. You need to conform to their ideals. They have an interesting Patient Safety Friday meeting that serves as a dogma for their business model. Attend these religious gatherings once a week and follow what your Leader tells you to do.

They seem to only care about survey scores and numbers. The care of patients is often compromised because of this, which makes doing your job even more difficult.

Raises are given first to Senior Mangement, then to Directors, etc. Excellent and Strong ratings are hardly ever given to employees now. The managers can only give out a certain number of these ratings which are usually reserved for them.

job_title: Registered Nurse, Emergency Room in New York, NY
pros:
Theres a certain level of prestige that comes with working at the nations #5 Hospital and City's #1 Hospital.

The Pay is unparalleled with new grads making 98k before Night-Diff.

Hours are great as we work 3 days each week with a 4th once a scheduling period. Schedules are approved about 2 weeks in advance for the upcoming month. 

Co-workers in the Emergency Room are Amazing and very supportive and serve as role models for New Graduates.

The ability to move up the ladder is very evident as you will soon act as Team-Leader, Charge Nurse, and eventually can work your way up to becoming a Clinical Nurse Manager as long as you remain steadfast and passionate about the workplace.
cons:
Nurse to Patient Ratios in the ED are unbelievable sometimes ranging from 10-12 per Nurse. 

We have no ancillary staff to help support Nurses. Nurses are often overwhelmed having to do everything whereas on the floors, there are techs/aides who help out tremendously.

job_title: Unit Clerk in Brooklyn, NY
pros: NONE!  This location needs major cleaning of the  corruption and negligence that takes place in a prestige name such as New York Presbyterian
cons: Working here is like being a legal slave.  Its a Salem Witch Hunt and they enjoy torturing as well lynching the employees. High school pettiness and backstabbing abound. Patients complain about the rude staff. Too many lazy slow people counting the days until their retirement. High quality people who actually care about improving things are seen as a threat and laid off. It doesn't take long for staff to realize how conniving and sneaky management can be. It makes you question what are you doing wrong despite the fact you aren't doing anything wrong. The atmosphere is filled with negative energy and If you express any of the frustrations you have, (to which nothing will be done about by rude and incompetent HR & Union personnel), you are seen as the problem and they will ruin your name and work on pushing you out. Don’t be fooled a lot of corruption taking place , it is a bureaucratic organization.
